An original puzzle-platformer with some very cool electromagnetics-based game mechanics. 

It took a while for me to get the hang of it, and to be honest the lack of guidance can be a little frustrating at times when you're still trying to figure out the precise way everything needs to be done in order to get where you need to go (and/or not die - note that you have no HP in this game, so taking any damage sends you back to the start of the room). But on the other hand this means that the storytelling is entirely visual, and it really adds to the sense of exploration and discovery. Plus, the hand-drawn art style is very nice and definitely fits the vibe of the setting and storyline, both of which unfold gradually as you progress.

So even though it can be somewhat infuriating when you accidentally and repeatedly catapult yourself directly into an electrified barrier or laser, or fall out of a 20-story tree just as you reach the top, or miss your platform in the vortex cylinder and have to float all the way back up again... it's definitely still enjoyable, and all the different ways that the simple positive-negative basis is used to create puzzles, obstacles, and transportation are pretty neat. 

I'd recommend it to anyone who enjoys platforming games, though you'll probably have a lot more fun with it if you're okay with having to think strategically and don't mind figuring it all out as you go along.

122788144.review:
[i]Teslagrad[/i] is a sidescrolling platformer where you play a young renegade electromagnetism wizard on the run from a corrupted king and his soldiers.  (Such was life in Teslagrad -- to be sung to Billy Joel's "Leningrad.")

Controls are few, with WASD for look/movement, space for jump, and arrow keys for abilities that you earn incrementally. Even in 2D, I'm not a strong navigator. (To this day, you can still catch me checking which hand's index finger and thumb make an L, because I get left and right confused sometimes.) Left and right arrow keys are magnetic polarity in this game, with one as blue and the other as red. On top of this, another arrow key toggles the magnet's mode (i.e., laser that player shoots or aura that surrounds player). So while the controls are few, I would say they're not necessarily simple: Controls coordination is part of solving the puzzles in this game.

The puzzles themselves are challenging and engaging. I'm not a strong electromagnetism thinker -- think I got less on an exit exam for my Physics II class than I did on an entry exam; it can be pretty counterintuitive stuff.  But the game's friendly "per-room" auto-save/checkpoint system makes it easy to experiment with the world and your character's abilities in order to find a solution. A majority of the game takes place inside a massive dungeon with a long shaft that about 100-ish rooms branch in and out of. (There may be more rooms than I think, because I believe rooms show up on the map only after you've visited them.) Progress for the most part is linear, but you can refer to the map to remind yourself how to get back to a room if you need to. And I needed to, to pick up some achievements, which (unfortunately, I felt) do not appear on the map.

Achievements appear in the game as battery/scroll tokens that are "off the beaten path" of the game's typical linear progression. [spoiler]It's worth your while to collect them as you find them, though, because you need some to unlock the last part of the game.[/spoiler] This playthrough I wanted to play to the game's end, but I would play it again to collect all its achievements.

Achievements also serve as one of the game's mechanisms for developing the story. Think I got this one about the same time as (and maybe even because of) [i]Limbo[/i] and [i]Inside[/i], which also have wordless/visual story development. For each achievement you collect, you get a card that unveils a little bit more about the story. These cards can be viewed together (in a screen near the map) to make a mosaic outline of the story. Story dev also happens in-game in several "puppet play" rooms that you come across while navigating the dungeon. I've only collected about half the achievements, but from what I could tell, the story is that [spoiler]your character belongs to a group of magicians who helped a king come into power by helping him succeed in battle, but they are now being hunted down because they refused to help him in other battles.[/spoiler]

Game mood alternates between somber and cartoonish. The drawing of the playable character reminds me a lot of "Calvin and Hobbes," some assets reminded me of [i]Rayman[/i], and the backgrounds look like they could have come from a classic Disney film. I thought I picked up a few cultural references too, to [i]Ghostbusters[/i], for example. Sound effects are well-chosen and I didn't mind hearing them repeatedly in rooms I had a hard time in. The soundtrack was good, not at all distracting, and sometimes very effective at getting you pumped up to tackle a puzzle/boss.

One thing that stood out to me in the credits is just how many alpha playtesters the game had. (Especially compared to the rest of the crew!) And it showed! I don't think I ran into any bugs in this game.

I expected this one to take 5-7 hours but it took me about twice that. (I have 13 hours total, but one or two of those was from a partial playthrough a while back.) I may have been able to bring it down a little by collecting achievements as I saw them, because you have to play room(s) over if you don't get the achievement the first time round.

The world is beautiful and it's fun to explore. After you complete climbing the tower which will probably take you 2-3 hours, you'll open up a lower floor. You need 15 scrolls to open that floor up so you can get to exploring, see which areas you missed, and grab some more scrolls to open up the path. There is a "true" ending after finding all 36 scrolls but after playing, I don't really have much desire to find it.

For the issues, some of the checkpoints are so poorly placed. Sometimes it takes time to set up a slow and tedious puzzle to attempt your jump. If that jump is very difficult to perform, you're going to be sitting there setting it up over and over again, taking your time because of how slow the game mechanics can be. One instance that was very tedious was late in the game when you had to roll a ball with your magnetic cloak. Rolling it off the platform above you took about 5-10 seconds because of how slow the ball rolls. That doesn't seem long, right? Well that jump afterwards was very difficult. I probably spent 5 minutes attempting that jump with 3-4 minues of that time just watching that ball roll on every reset.

Some of the bosses were fun while others weren't. Particularly the boss that shoots the energy orbs at you. It just felt like total RNG to attack the boss because you had to pull the energy balls back at the boss with your magnetic cloak and they were very hard to aim. They also only lasted a few seconds each so sometimes they'd disappear right before hitting the boss. The last boss was also just frustrating and unfun with how quickly his attacks move with your dash cooldown sometimes getting you killed. One of the tedious parts of the boss fights was that you had to hit them 3 times each to defeat them. You'd have to avoid their attacks, sometimes up to a minute or two before you get an opportunity to attack, then you can hit them once. The problem is that for every boss, the first two attacks were always easy. The last attack was hard to hit without dying. So you'd find yourself repeating the same 2-3 minutes for the start of the boss fight and if you're having trouble on the third, die, and repeat, sitting there getting frustrated and bored.

Fortunately, there are 5 bosses and only 2 of them really felt tedious and unfun. The general exploration and puzzle solving was fun and I did enjoy most of my time in the game. It's just after completing it, while not seeing the "true" ending, I just have no desire to keep going to see it. Beating the game with the minimal scrolls collected only took about 15 minutes and the game wasn't bad in that time but not bad isn't good enough for me to want more. 

The game is pretty interesting if you want to pick it up on a sale or see it in a bundle if you're interested in puzzle/platformers. If you're not into puzzle/platformers, just skip this one entirely.

121039776.review:
A beautiful metroidvania puzzle-platformer with creative mechanics centered around magnetic powers and array of well-designed puzzles that test the player’s ingenuity.

The protagonist is a young boy who escapes from enemy army invading his village into a tower built years ago by a group of scholars, now abandoned. Inside he discovers series of inventions, starting with a pair of gloves, that allows him to manipulate magnetic fields. As the tower is filled with various challenges centered around magnetism, he works his way up to discover the truth behind the invasion and find a way to stop it.

As you can guess based on the above description, the plot is a standard fare for video games: there’s a bad guy, stop the bad guy. However, the story exceeds in the way it’s told. There’s no dialogues throughout the game. Instead at specific sections of the tower you’ll enter various theaters where puppet shows are played, revealing bit by bit the backstory; you can either watch or ignore them. Furthermore, you can collect various scrolls hidden around the tower that provide additional info. The way storytelling is handled means the player not only can completely ignore the plot if they’re not interested, but can also adjust their own difficulty to an extend as the scrolls often require solving more challenging puzzles.

Speaking of the puzzles, they’re brilliantly designed and challenging. This isn’t one of those games where you can leisurely work on the solution. No, the protagonist dies in one hit, so between rare enemies and numerous hazards you need to always think and act fast. If that sounds like a recipe for a frustrating experience, it isn’t. Tight controls, quick pace and checkpoint at the start of each room means that in the case of death - and those will happen regularly - you never loose much progress.

You can’t attack regular enemies until you pick up you final upgrade, but thankfully they’re fairly scarce. However, you can and have to fight during boss battles. Yes, there are boss battles. I wish more indie games featured those.

The bosses work as a check-up on how well you mastered abilities at your disposal like boss fights in all well-designed metroidvania titles; whatever is the newest tool you acquired, that’s what you need to use against each baddy. And they’re tricky too, forcing you to learn their pattern before you can defeat them.

Hard but fair. Beautiful and creative. Easily one of the best games I’ve ever played.

10/10

I know a number of  games of similar style that make you do some fetch quest at the end to force you to go back through the various areas and explore, but I find that this just breaks up the flow of games, especially in Teslagrad, since the map itself is fairly linear, and doesn't really offer that much in terms of exploration because of its puzzle-oriented gameplay. The 15 required scrolls feel pretty unnecessary, other than to show off how the beams and cloak are OP in some puzzles. Honestly, the game could be better off with just the optional 36 scrolls and the alternate ending (but I found that this extra ending wasn't a great payoff for going the extra several miles, especially since I didn't really understand the significance of it, but that could be because I didn't watch most of the stage puppet show things throughout the game). Boss fights feel fairly balanced, except the last two kind of seemed like massive difficulty spikes when doing a blind playthrough. Once I figured out stuff, these fights were almost completely muscle memory, but the difficulty was compounded by unnecessary issues that are mentioned below. So far I mentioned subjective matters, so I will switch gears to some more objective issues.

There are two major problems I have with this game: 1) when dashing across a hazardous (but 'dashable') barrier, while moving left or right and/or jumping, sometimes the game lets you live, but other times it just kills you. In either case, I can see that the character clears the barrier, and yet is still burned to crisp for no reason (this is especially common in the last two battles). This makes the maneuver risky, since the outcome is inconsistent. This is why I avoid jumping or pressing left or right when dashing (it guarantees survival across barriers if you time things correctly). But this strategy has its own problems, because it limits the time you have to move off of the ground in the final boss fight with the king, a battle in which it is critical to move swiftly to avoid crown beams and the spinning swords, which occupy most of the arena. 2) Speaking of the king fight, today I encountered a glitch in which the crown got stuck on the left side of the arena with its beam active (and the game got soft-locked), so I spent some time dodging the swords and looking at the king's frozen angry expression before offing myself on the beam to restart the fight. [/spoiler]

Make no mistake, I like this game because it is a really creative idea that sells itself well throughout the first half of the game. I have been meaning to finish it in the past several years because I felt that it deserved some attention. I found similar technical issues in other indie games such as Super Daryl Deluxe, which had some glitches that diminished my overall perception of the game (coincidentally, one of them was also a soft-lock in the final fight). These are inspiring and creative indie games that could use another patch or two. I am not aware of any newer releases from your team, but I imagine I will take a look at more of your work in the coming days, since this game managed to grab my attention. I hope this somehow helps, even though it has been a number of years since the initial release. Keep up the solid work!

Teslagrad is a platformer like none other that I've played. I started playing it on a whim, and keep coming back to it to experience its beauty another time. In more detail (some minor spoilers ahead):

1. )   The bosses have a major learning curve (one boss comes to mind that has 3 unique phases and no "checkpoints" during the fight). In my experience, if you are able to complete a boss fight, you usually have learned the boss's moves and phases to a degree that the boss won't pose too much of a problem. I am not exceptionally gifted at platformers, but the fact that one specific boss [spoiler](Guerickes Orb)[/spoiler] took me more than 2 hours out of my 10 hour initial run speaks to the difficulty of the boss fights. The payoff is an incredible feeling of satisfaction once you manage to defeat each boss.

2.)   Although the one-hit-kill mechanic is certainly controversial and makes the boss fights exceptionally difficult, in my opinion it makes Teslagrad more unique in a better way. This mechanic forces you to plan your course of action, whether you are dodging electified boxes flying through the air or attempting to get a Volt Walker into one of those big, lavaproof robots. This is exemplified by Grues, which appear as the sole aggressive enemy in the game. As you cannot withstand even one hit from a Grue, you are instead required to avoid them, which contrasts with many Metroidvania games I've played. This gives the silent protagonist a different playstyle.

3.)   Teslagrad's gimmick is magnetism, and it does an excellent job of theming platforming and its classic and new Metroidvania abilities in a magnetic steampunk feel. In no way is the magnetism mechanic perfect, but it is unique, well implemented, and exceptionally enjoyable. The magnet-fueled cloak ability is by far my favorite of all four abilities, both because of its role in the gameplay and that it is very enjoyable to use. 

All in all, I cannot recommend Teslagrad more to anyone who likes unique, enjoyable platformers. Its story, told mostly through wordless puppet shows, is a delight on the surface and quite fascinating if one enjoys digging into game lore. The one must-do in my opinion is collecting all the scrolls, as the process of backtracking to collect all your missed scrolls gives you an appreciation for the mechanics of the game. Though your journey through the Tesla Tower is arduous at times, it is absolutely worth it for the joy that this game brings. 

TLDR Rating: ★★★★★

Seemed like it could be so good. Magnetism-based platform puzzles? Awesome. Steampunk hand-drawn aesthetic? Super. You need to make a jump, holding right all the time; set your polarity to blue at the start of it, less than halfway through switch your polarity to red, then use ability 2 less than a second into the jump. You need to do a magnetic version of log rolling, while doing magnetism-assisted power jumps then use an ability to skip through instant death electricity beams; and you need to do the whole thing fast.

I love platform puzzlers, and this is... enough of a platform puzzler for me to play to somewhere past the third boss... but it is more of a precision platformer than a platform puzzler, and that's what doomed it for me.

Recommended if you have a controller, superb platforming reflexes, a taste for puzzles, and the patience to put up with dying hundreds of times. Otherwise... it has some lovely ideas, and the puzzles are good, but it's more frustration than it's worth to get from "I know what to do" to "I [i]finally[/i] managed to do it".

74649112.review:
[b]TL;DR Summary: A fun puzzle game, but that requires far more precision platforming than one might expect, or be willing to work through.[/b] 

Welcome to Teslagrad, a dark and dreary city heavily inspired by the imagery of early communism and the dystopia that followed. Of course, that means you won't exactly be enjoying the sights, as you flee for your young life from the soldiers that suddenly come breaking down your door. The long abandoned great tower that once was home to the electricity wielding Teslamancers may seem like a sanctuary, but it has its own secrets and dangers...but also rewards for those able to overcome its challenges. 

Merging two-dimensional platforming with  logical conundrums, Teslagrad presents itself as a "puzzlevania", and while nothing in it is particularly unique or revolutionary, it does present a mostly enjoyable experience in a well-done hand-drawn animated style. But the key word in that sentence is mostly. 

On the positive, I genuinely enjoyed the puzzle side of Teslagrad. Built around the simple principles of magnetism, using polarity flips to attract or repel not only blocks, but also yourself, there are a surprising variety of challenges with an almost perfect learning curve, as though I did not need to use a guide to progress through the story or find all 36 achievement scrolls, I definitely had to hunt and think to earn them all. So this half - which I would consider the actual soul of the game - is well done.

I do have to say though, the store description is a bit misleading about the other half. I bought Teslagrad expecting a metroidvania, but it really isn't one. Yes, it has room to room progression, and earned ability upgrades that alter gameplay, but it is highly linear, and the very limited number of abilities are hard-locked into that line. The only time I ever left linear progression was to backtrack for achievement scrolls that were unattainable until some ability was added, but that isn't free roaming exploration, it's just a "ha ha, you're going to have to come back for this later". Furthermore, for most of the game you have no way to attack or fight enemies. Instead, the puzzles are accented, and often directly combined, with a medium-difficulty hardcore platformer, where all you can do is dodge hazards and/or enemies and failure to execute perfect mechanics leads to instant death, as your character cannot take even a single hit. This means that in addition to figuring out the steps to complete the puzzle, you then need to actually move through the room, often with little margin for error. You get infinite lives, and respawn at the start of the room you died in, so usually this isn't horribly punishing. But for boss fights - particularly the last two - this does become a recipe for frustration, as the only way to learn the attack patterns is to succumb to them, over and over and over until you actually learn what to expect. This isn't just about reflexes, in some instances you need to learn where to be at certain times to not be caught in a trap that is unavoidable by the time it can be seen. Personally, I found these last two bosses "cheap", and more frustrating than fun, and without much sense of accomplishment once I cleared them. Hitboxes often feel off, amplifying these issues, and in general, I don't think this kind of unforgiving precision fits in what is (and should be) at its core primarily a puzzle game. 

So in short, not the greatest game I've ever played, but worth a run through at the asking price. Just know that if you're not both willing and able to execute the mechanics, you may end up having to ragequit.

I really tried to give this game a solid chance. Played it the whole way through, got every achievement. It just wasn't worth it. Honestly, for the first half, I was going to give it a fair "meh" leaning more into the negative side of things. The last few puzzles and bits threw it so hard into "god I despise this game" that it was honestly shocking.

A big problem with this game is that it is, obviously, a physics game due to how it uses magnets, and the physics are...finicky. Really finicky. There were many times where I thought something absolutely should've been fine to work, and instead I sat there trying five-ten times just to get one thing done because the physics were having none of that. 

And oh my god, it did not pay off to have a mini-teleport effect in the game. It's quite annoying because of the way it functions. It essentially allows you to hop forward a few steps, which is usually fine...except it doesn't tell you where it's putting you, which can lead to you ever so slightly under/overshooting things. This wouldn't be an incredibly big issue in my mind if it weren't for how precise the game expects you to be in some parts. There is one puzzle in particular (which is actually the puzzle that drove me to change my rating to negative!) that detracts SO MUCH from the experience because of the lack of clear visibility on where the teleport is going that I couldn't help but be surprised that the creators genuinely thought the puzzle was a good idea to put into the game. For those of you who already played the game and are reading this out of boredom or otherwise, yes, I am talking about the electric barrier "maze."

I also, generally speaking, think the game turned more from interesting puzzles to cheap, annoying bits that served mainly to waste time. (Particularly evident with only the first boss really being any sort of "puzzle" and the others all being much more standard "dodge hit, take your own shot" types) It doesn't help that if you screw something up, you need to expect that you'll be backtracking. This includes in boss fights, because hey, guess what, you have one HP. That's it, you get hit once and you're done. Boss fights tend to also include cheap shots in them so you're basically guaranteed to need to restart at least once just from a surprise shot added into the second or third phase of a fight. But even in normal gameplay, you should probably just be prepared to fall off of something because you just barely mistimed your teleport, and now you'll just be redoing an entire section. Hope you wanted that.

The story is very generic as well, definitely nothing to write home about. Not a big deal in a game like this, but I figured I'd note that yeah, there is one, and yeah, it's really just nothing special. It doesn't help that if you want the full picture you absolutely have to get all of the collectibles in the game.

...Well, that's what I'd like to say, but if you look at the store page for this game, it absolutely tries to brag in an incredibly obnoxious way about how good the story is without even needing a single line of dialogue.
So yeah, it's a generic, semi-walled off, boring story with nothing unique about it. I felt nothing for it.

Honestly though? The biggest problem with this game? Even at the start, I wouldn't say I was incredibly impressed with the puzzles, but the further I got in the game, the more I thought I could just be playing something better that I actually enjoyed. Like this game offered nothing that I couldn't get somewhere else, and I wouldn't be bored/mildly annoyed while doing it. And because it was just pushing out more and more finnicky puzzles, it just got more irritating without any satisfaction of thinking I did well.

I see this game is considered "very positive" on steam, and I get it! I can see how someone could like this. It's certainly not for me though, and I would keep in consideration that the game does have fussy physics and a much poorer latter half to it, coupled with a weak story that doesn't particularly invest the player in progression.

That having been said, I will also point out this game is incredibly short, with a lot of my total time on the game being spent on me being...mostly stupid (as well as time tabbed out talking on discord). I would definitely put that in mind considering that this was my first time playing the game and I only have this much time spent on it with a 100% completed save file. There are gameplay videos on youtube of people getting 100% in the game in roughly an hour without speedrunning. It's just...really short. It's not an expensive game by any means, but I'm putting this out here right now for anyone on the fence involving the length of the game.

I also went through some of the other reviews before finally posting up mine, and a big complaint I saw over and over again is that the game does not make it clear that you HAVE to get a good chunk of the collectibles or you are just hardlocked out of the final boss unless you start backtracking through things. I didn't really think about this problem since I'm a completionist anyway, but yeah, I can see how that's extremely insulting and comes out of left field, especially with absolutely no indication about where any of the collectibles are.

Proceed with caution getting this game. The bad part will likely come for you after the refund window is over. It may be better to just watch it and enjoy the art on youtube.

The main thing is magnetism. Most things are red/blue, opposites attract and same color repels. Some objects' polarity can be changed by you, some can't, some are stationary, some aren't, puzzle away. And tractor beams. 
Although there's story, there are no npcs, there's no chat, there's not even writing. I think the language option is only for the menu. Every new mechanic is explained at most by some hieroglyphs, but you only have a few buttons, you can figure it out.
At first you can only get a charge by touching bugs, then you get gloves for punching objects red/blue, then you get a dash, a cloak to make yourself red/blue, and finally [spoiler]a ranged upgrade for the gloves.[/spoiler]
There's five puzzle bosses, each using a new mechanic beatable by your latest upgrade, and 36 semi-optional batteries hidden throughout the world for a better ending. They're not too hidden, look up/down in every location and you'll see them, but getting them is sometimes trickier.
Overall a smooth puzzle experience with charming graphics, atmospheric music, and intuitive physics.

It is clear that Teslagrad is primarily a puzzle game but, when viewed through the lens of the metroidvania genre (which the steam tags do include), Teslagrad shines as an example of how a developer can supplant typical metroidvania systems with new ones. In the case of Teslagrad, combat was almost entirely replaced with a puzzle world that keeps the exploration, item based progression, and atmosphere of a metroidvania; this effectively keeps the genre fresh for players like me.  Beyond what Teslagrad does for the metroidvania genre, the game stands on its own two feet without pinning it to a tag. The puzzles are clever and have alternative methods to obtain the many collectables. I have never played a game where every optional collectable the player acquires is its own Steam achievement: it makes the collectathon exponentially rewarding. I have plans to do the collectathon but this is where I have some minor issues with the game. Teslagrad is very very short: I beat the game with half of the collectables in four hours. I really could not believe it when I looked at my play time afterwards. Obviously my hours will increase as I do the collectathon but that is a ridiculously short game. However, if you noticed how I described the length, Teslagrad did not feel short. I found it slightly tedious at times because any wrong move into a hazard means instant death and starts the player at the beginning of the room. I want to reinstate that these were only minor issues and Teslagrad as a whole gets my recommendation to puzzle game and metroidvania players.
The bosses were suited towards the game wonderfully. Most of the games I have been playing and reviewing lately have had combat, but Teslagrad is a puzzle game. The bosses in Teslagrad are in a similar setting to Yoku’s Island Express but I believe Teslagrad achieved more rewarding and intense boss fights by far. The bosses may be puzzles but they are scary; it really is like picking apart the move set of a Dark Souls boss but rather than openings for hitting them… they are openings for the puzzle.  The bosses are not overwhelmingly difficult but that is a great move on the design because the player dies in one hit. There was only one boss I would say is sub-par but that is it: the bosses were all unique, fun to fight, and admittedly scary. I think this game is a real sleeper for boss fighters out there and is worth a try as long as you remember Teslagrad is not a combat game; it is a puzzle game.

A very short but beautiful 2D puzzle platformer! I put in about 10 hours to 100% complete the game.
While it's obvious that you can't put much of a story into less than 10 hours of gameplay, the story told here shines not by its complexity, but by its presentation. Although you never lose track of the story, there's a dozen different ways to interpret it which gives the games quite the unique depth.
Compared to other platformers/metroidvanias, Teslagrad introduces an interesting way to set a higher difficulty. There's no health bar and if you get hit once, you die. This especially makes for pretty hard boss fights. Unlike a lot of other games, you rarely feel frustrated because there's always something you can improve on and it rarely depends on pure skill or dexterity.
The gameplay itself, however, does not include any fighting mechanics. All enemies and boss "fights" are solved through puzzling. The puzzling parts are very well implemented and demonstrate interesting ways to utilize pole mechanics. 

All in all, I thoroughly enjoyed the few hours I put into the game and did find myself spending 4-5 hours at a time trying to figure out certain tricky parts of the game.

63569628.review:
Is Teslagrad a good game? Yea, mostly. 
Is Teslagrad an enjoyable experience? Yea, [i]mostly[/i].
Would I recommend Teslagrad? Yea, [b]mostly[/b].

Before I get properly started with the review, I just want to say that I went into Teslagrad expecting it to be a metroidvania. 
[b]Teslagrad is not a metroidvania.[/b]

Teslagrad is a platformer, leaning towards puzzle-platformer, with 5 boss fights thrown in for good measure.
However, Teslagrad's first noticeable shortcoming is its controls. I play with a controller (and, as such, can't speak for the keyboard controls) and not being able to switch between the left analog stick and the d-pad to move in a game like this felt absolutely awful. Playing with the joysticks made the character feel way too floaty and imprecise with their movements, however using the d-pad worked out well instead, making the character feel a little more responsive, which was good.
It's second big flaw, in my opinion, are its boss fights. They're just not particularly good, honestly. They come out of absolutely nowhere (as there isn't any combat at all in the entire rest of the game) and they aren't particularly memorable ~ I just 100%ed the game in a single sitting and I had to google how many bosses there actually were because I could only remember 3 of them). The most memorable boss, for me anyway, is probably the first boss ~ simply because the encounter basically came out of nowhere while I was just looking around mindlessly.

However, if you go into the game with the right expectations, Teslagrad can be a pretty decent time.

It's not particularly long (it took me a little over 7 hours to get 100% completion and that's including a little time spent afk), but I personally think it was a good length for what it was. [This also gets a strong recommendation for an easy 100% if anybody cares about that.]

Teslagrad's puzzles and platforming revolve almost exclusively around magnets. You're either making two objects attract/repel each other, or you're sticking yourself to a block, or you're being repelled by something.. That's pretty much it. And, while that might sound like a criticism, it's actually not. Because of the game's short length and that fact that Teslagrad's puzzles/platforming sections have a steadily increasing difficulty curve, Teslagrad feels like it's focusing on trying to do one thing really well, rather than lots of things poorly.
The platforming and exploration in this are definitely the high points for me.

The game's visuals are nice. They didn't leave a very strong impression on me, but I also didn't encounter any graphical glitches or bugs in my entire time spent playing with it.

Come to think of it, I didn't come across any bugs or glitches during my entire time playing. So the game gets a 10/10 on reliability (at least from me).

Overall I'm glad I played Teslagrad.
A decent game, and an easy 100%.
...Let down a little by some dodgy boss fights.
7/10

Full disclosure: as of this writing, I haven't finished this game. It has the all the makings of something decent (not great, decent), but it's also full of all kinds of little design screw-ups that collectively tried my patience to its breaking point. I was close to the end, so maybe I'll pick this back up and finish it after I've cooled down for a while, but Teslagrad has not been a fun experience for me. 

There's no health bar; if you get hit at all, you're dead. This is supposed to be offset by the fact that your character respawns infinitely at either the beginning of the newest room you entered, or at various invisible checkpoints were the room is especially large and filled with frustrating puzzles. Which brings me to the next thing: this game is advertised as a Metroid-style experience. It isn't. At all. If someone took the barest hint of a Metroid template and made a puzzle game around the mechanics of electromagnetism over the top of it, that's what this game is. 

After a short intro sequence where you run away from some soldiers, you enter the tower of the Teslamancers, at which point you work (and it *is* work) your way through a series of puzzle rooms that form a serpentine path that criss-crosses the tower's central shaft. As you make your way through these rooms, you will sometimes be challenged to find a way to reach scrolls which are typically placed in hard-to-reach places. You have to collect at least 15 of these to open the gate to the final area. Also, if you don't get *every single one of them*, you can't get the true ending. For some of them, if you miss a very narrow window of opportunity to collect them, you have to go through the entire area they're found in to get the same narrow window of opportunity again. 

I've barely scratched the surface of all the little frustrations that are packed into this game. Do I recommend it? No way. This game is way too much work for no payoff.

[h1]Full Review[/h1]
I don’t usually talk about visuals in my reviews, primarily because readers can make their own judgements on that topic just by checking screens of the game, but for this game I think there’s a relevant analogy. Personally I love [i]Teslagrad’s[/i] hand-animated style – just the visual aesthetic is inviting and the animations only get more creative toward the end of the game. However one of the first things that struck me starting this game was how bland the sound design is. Your story opens up with your child protagonist running from fascist government law enforcement, and it’s weirdly silent. What could have been an exciting chase scene to set the tone for the rest of the game instead felt confusing to me; it was a void in the presentation juxtaposed against what would otherwise be beautiful. This dissonance between artistic elements is unfortunately like all the other elements of the game as well. The core gameplay – like the art – is clever, unique, and praiseworthy. Some of the content design however – especially the bosses – are lacking, or perhaps simply inappropriate. Just like how some people who play their games with the volume down might not be as bothered by the sound design, many will be willing to overlook [i]Teslagrad’s[/i] weaknesses and enjoy this game fully. Others might find themselves throwing their controllers in frustration and lamenting what could have been. 

[i]Teslagrad[/i] is more similar to room-based puzzle games like [i]Portal[/i] or more appropriately [i]Supraland[/i]. Your goal is to simply move to the next room, but the method to move forward involves puzzling together environmental elements using progressively more complex gadgetry. All of the puzzles in the game are centered around magnetism. Positive and negative magnetic energy is represented by red and blue colors, opposites attract and same colors repel each other.  Manipulating these properties lets you float blocks into position, or even fly through the air yourself. 

Physics based puzzlers like this live or die on the level design, and thankfully for [i]Teslagrad[/i] this is the best part of the game. Combining the Puzzle Platformer with Metroidvania style ability upgrades is proven once again to be a fantastic way to keep things fresh and exciting. Each zone has you mastering ideas and gadgets, allowing you to move forward into the next area with the next new idea layered on. Because of how progression works, the game is fairly linear, but you are rewarded for going back to previous areas with new skills. Ultimately, in fact, you HAVE to do this a little bit. After you’ve collected the final power-up you’re presented with a gate that requires you to find around half of the game’s optional collectables to progress. If you’ve played [i]Metroid Prime[/i] and you hated the last-minute artifact hunting in that game, it’s a lot like that. I personally like exploring around, but in general doing it through puzzle platforming without a lot of short cut mechanics mixed in isn’t really my cup of tea. You get a much better ending if you collect every single item in the game, but personally I was done with it after the bare minimum. If you’re astute you may not have to explore at all to achieve at least this. 

The controls in [i]Teslagrad[/i] have a high potential to be frustrating, thanks to having to keep track of what switching colors is going to do to your character, but for the most part the game keeps to one type of magnetism at any given time. There’s a bit of a missed opportunity there to [i]really[/i] challenge the player with these mechanics, but there’s also the occasional puzzle that makes you grateful that they never did. One or two of the later puzzles felt less like I was solving the thing and more that I was playing an insane pachinko machine except with a confused boy inside of it. It’s entirely possible that my perceived solution wasn’t what was intended by the developers, but nevertheless my experience in some parts was more messing with the controls rather than guiding my character through a puzzle. This reliance on player dexterity over intellect might catch some players off-guard, especially if you were expecting a more brainy activity based on early impressions of the game. 

The biggest reason twitch-based control becomes an issue later in the game is that you always die in one hit. In the regular puzzle levels this isn’t a big deal since checkpoints are plentiful, but when you have to fly up an elevator shaft dodging spikes or especially with the bosses, this one-hit death rule completely changes the mood of the game. The bosses especially feel completely out of place. They play out much more like those arcade quicktime event games, like [i]Dragon’s Lair[/i], rather than a puzzle platformer. I personally thought some of the bosses were really clever, but having to repeat the entire sequence from the beginning because of one mistake got old really fast. It just seems completely unnecessary to make it so punishing – even giving the player one extra chance would have changed the entire experience. And, of course, the last impression the game leaves on you is a long boss fight using these mechanics. It’s not that boss fights like these can’t be fun, it’s just in the context of a puzzle platformer it kind of forces you to play a game you might not want to play when all you really want to do is have fun with magnet puzzles. 

As long as you’re aware that this game gets a little punishing later on, I think you’ll still find an overall enjoyable experience. [i]Teslagrad[/i] is both beautiful and unique, two traits that make it worth considering alone. But like how its sound design doesn’t match up to its magnificent animated visuals, you may find that the gameplay clashes with itself just a little. If the ideas were separated into two different games they both might have been great individually, but as-is it narrows the niche of players that will wholly enjoy every element this game has to offer. What’s left is still a very much above average indie title, it just falls a little short of “great”, in my opinion.

3.5 out of 5

53643502.review:
To speak on the positive first:

The graphics are great. The storytelling is amazing, I love background storytelling. The more attention you pay to scribbles on the wall and the posters around the place, the more you understand what's going on.

The controls work well, though controlling your movements when pushing or pulling off magnetic blocks can be a bit iffy. It's hard to tell which direction you're going to fly off in or how far you'll go.

The concept itself is interesting also, using magnetism to navigate and solve puzzles.

So why can't I recommend it?

[h1]The boss fights.[/h1]

This is a PUZZLE game. Where the majority of the time, you get to scope out a room, figure out what to do, plan your attempts, then keep at it until you get it.
But the boss fights? Twitch-based action gameplay where you have maybe 0.5 of a second between phases to dodge the attack you didn't know was coming. Many of the boss fights don't even involve the magnetic mechanics. It's just getting close or behind them, and whalloping them, then dodge all its attacks until you can hit it again.

It's just so jarring to the puzzle gameplay elsewhere to see the game's own mechanics ignored the moment a boss shows up. A couple of them do involve making use of the magnetism, but the further into the game you go, the more they get ignored and the more twitch reactions become your way to win.

This is the one that bothered me the most. Puzzle games, with puzzle mechanics, need puzzle solutions to encounters. Not action punch/shoot the boss.

[h1]Lack of puzzle variety[/h1]

Many of the puzzles involve blinking through a barrier, and hanging off the ceiling by attracting yourself to the magnet above. It's the same thing throughout the game, the same few puzzles.

This isn't sooo bad, I just wanted this mechanic pushed further. More variety in how you can mess with magnetism to get through rooms.

There were a few rooms that had interesting elements, such as moving a ball around using your own magnetism, whilst you pushed off to reach higher areas. But these rooms were rare. Most common were straightforward blink through the gate and hang off the ceiling rooms.

[h1]The Scrolls[/h1]

I don't mind optional pickups like the scrolls. I don't mind a true ending being locked behind collecting them all.

I do mind the final area of the game being locked behind a minimum number of them when nothing was said throughout the game to inform me of this until right at the door to the final boss' area.


[h1]Overall[/h1]

This is not a BAD game, in many ways it's very good. But the sameyness of the puzzles combined with the non-puzzle-like bosses I consider to be such poor design I can't in good conscience recommend it.

53467201.review:
This looks like a Platventure on the surface, but it's mostly linear.  Every room is its own puzzle to solve, and over the course of the adventure, you get a few upgrades that let you solve new puzzles, reach new areas, and sometimes traverse old areas much more efficiently.  The only real backtracking is if you want to grab all of the collectibles, which neither myself nor the entire Internet can reach a consensus as to whether they're supposed to be scrolls, batteries, or cylindrical tarot cards.  I guess batteries would make the most sense, since you use magnetism to solve almost every puzzle; most of your upgrades revolve around this principle.  This leads to some extraordinary boss fights, as well; each of them is very clever and challenging.

The game's biggest problem is the physics engine.  If they'd gone with something a little more video-gamey, it would've been fine, but this is a more in-depth physics engine.  That might sound like a good thing, but the problem is that there are a lot of random elements to everything.  There are a few challenges that only require you to know what you're doing and have the reflexes to do it, but there are several that have a strong element of chance to them.  I've even seen some pretty skilled-looking players' YouTube videos, and even they struggle with a good handful of them, so I don't think it's just me.  This applies to boss fights, as well; clever as they are, all it takes is one errant newton to screw you over and put you back at square one.  Thankfully, every room is a checkpoint (some have several), but a few of them really drag on.  Despite all of that, I did manage to beat the game and get everything, so with a little perseverance, it should be possible.

All in all, I do recommend Teslagrad, if you can handle moderate frustration, if for no other reason than the unique ideas in play here.

I've now finished the game - true ending and all.
And I have mixed feelings about this game.

I'll start with the good part - the basis of the game is good. There are a lot of different, interesting puzzles, with magnets as the main mechanic. The game keeps adding new mechanics to keep things fresh, and it works. There's no hand-holding in this game, which means you always figure out the puzzles by yourself, thus making them even more satisfying.
The animation is great and the music is great as well. The rooms are varied and beautiful, and make me feel sorry the story doesn't live up to them.

Now, the bad parts. I have a lot to say here, but it doesn't mean it's bad enough to ruin my experience.
The physics of the game can get in the way of the game, occasionaly. This problem really shows at puzzles like the production belt part and scroll #15. This can lead to some puzzles being more of a struggle against the physics engine than anything else.
The open-level design is really pointless, besides getting the scrolls (collectibles) you missed, and it could easily have been fixed with a level select or a teleporter room, instead of the loooong elevator shaft. There aren't any interesting connections between the levels, and the few bad and long puzzles really stick out when you're going back through them. It's unfun to re-solve puzzles you already did.
The story isn't told through dialogue, it's told through cutscene rooms where there are plays in the background and the collectibles. The creators seem to be very proud of this, but on the whole it doesn't add much to it. it just means you can skip it for the most part. It isn't even that unique or interesting, it's simply a 'chosen hero' story with a corrupt king to destroy.  All this story does is give a setting for the game, and although there is an attempt at explaining what, how or why all of creatures, mechanics and bosses are there, for the most part it's nothing more than a picture of them being made or found, usually for no reason.

The bosses, like the game, are a mixed bag. On one hand, most of them are very unique and have interesting mechanics which they let you figure out by yourself. They're very puzzle-y and have phases, which for the most part get more difficult every time.
On the other hand there are too many cases of telgraphs which are too short or nonexistant, like the king's crown beam.
And you always die on the first hit, which always means going back through all the phases, which makes them feel immensely repetetive and tedious.

On the whole, this is a very good game wieghed down by some very bad and tedious flaws.

Listen, there's a lot of good elements to Teslagrad. I mean I've gone through and just about finished the entire game, only stopping at the final boss because there was a good chance I'd just smash my controller into a thousand pieces. I feel a little bad, because the game is presented so well. Nice animations, a subtle but fitting soundtrack and some great non-verbal storytelling.  The mechanics are very interesting on paper, and there's a lot of cool puzzle design ideas. I wouldn't have collected every scroll and solved all the puzzles if Teslagrad was straight up a bad game. But there's multiple fatal flaws, any one of which would have me hesitant to recommend this to others and all of which put me firmly in team thumbs down.

For starters, the best platforming games make it clear that when you die, it's your fault (ESPECIALLY platformers where one hit means death, like this one). You missed a button. You jumped too far. You reacted too slowly. Teslagrad has extremely "floaty" and non-deterministic physics, which means this is almost never the case. Whether it's because your blink button just didn't work (as it often does), or a hit box seems off of where it should be, it always feels like Teslagrad's engine screwed up, which always makes me feel like why am I still playing this game.

Momentum in the game is bizarre; if you're in a blue field, in theory the blue button should force you up, and the red button should suck you down. But if you're already moving downwards, the blue button does literally nothing. You need to give yourself upward momentum (eg jumping) and then hold down the blue button to continue flying upwards. And if you hit a wall or slow down for an obstacle, you'll sink back down. So many movement puzzles ended up with me throwing myself into these fields over and over, hoping this time the exact nanosecond I jumped would make a difference.

On top of this, a handful of segments feel like the game is a direct insult to your time. Let's talk about scroll 30, an infamously difficult challenge that even the developers feel is out of place for the game (according to the forums at least). Basically you need to hit a button to make a scroll rise quickly up a tower, then fling yourself upwards and blink through a series of instant death obstacles to beat it to the top. If you're too slow, the scroll whizzes by into a pipe (of course not stopping for a second) and you need to go back down and try again. 

To even get past the maze took me thirty or so tries, and I wasn't even close to catching the scroll. I practised, practised, practised (thirty more tries) until I could almost make it to the top at full speed, and eventually did so. But my fleeting sense of accomplishment was quashed, when the flipping scroll just never came up through the tube. I assumed it despawned because I moved too far ahead? Imagine how I felt, after finishing a ridiculous challenge, only for it to not count. It didn't count the second time I did it either (ten more tries) or the third, thinking that maybe I just missed the scroll or didn't wait long enough. I realized I needed to arbitrarily slow down so I didn't outpace the scroll, but not too much because you can't regain upward momentum. It was tedious and frustrating, and made me furious, but I stuck with it because it was the last scroll I needed and how could the rest of the game be worse than the optional content?

Then I got to the final boss, couldn't get a single hit on him, looked it up and saw I needed six hits on him, all without being hit once. So now I have the bizarre paradox of a Steam game with 100% achievements, that I actually haven't (and won't) finish.

In short, Teslagrad feels like it's stuck between emulating Super Meat Boy and Braid, but doesn't have a solid enough platforming base for either. It's not a bad game! Honestly if you have it already it's worth trying. But if you don't have the patience for frustrating physics and random giant difficulty spikes (like me!) you'll probably end up dropping it too.

I thought I didn't like platformers anymore. They were boring, or gimicky, or required insane twitch skills. But I started Teslagrad anyway, hoping for more.

And I got it.

Generally speaking, Teslagrad shares few flaws with its modern peers. It is a well-balanced, puzzle-based platformer where you acquire new abilities as you progress, and you can return almost anywhere anytime to search for collectibles.  It does require some crazy twitch skills at certain points, but it's mostly for optional objectives (electric fences during the floating sections, anyone?), and it doesn't happen enough to detract from the overall experience.

The boss fights are super fun. The level design and skill set make sense within the context of the world. And each time you gain a new ability it feels powerful and unique.

I would've preferred more story and lore, but what's there is enough to be motivating and push the plot forward. The only real negative is that the keyboard controls were not as tight as I would've liked. Definitely found myself frustrated with them a few times. I did try playing with the Steam controller, but it's a bad controller, as controllers go. Something like an Xbox controller would probably be the best option.

Good music. Fitting hand-drawn art. A story that shines in the beginning and the end, while the long middle carried by solid puzzles and gameplay. Simply put: Teslagrad is a great platformer.

45169270.review:
Bought this game on sale awhile back, and I just got around to playing.

Teslagrad is a platfomer Metroidvania, with a theme around magnetic and electric-based puzzles. Basically, there are blue and red magnetic poles, with attract the opposite color and repel their own color. You use this to manipulate blocks and eventually, even yourself, as you climb up the mysterious tower. 

In addition to the puzzles, the game also has a really interesting story/mythos. As the name "Tesla" might indicate, it's based in a world that may suggest a steampunk feel, but uses electricity in a pseudo-fantasy setting. What's also interesting is the way in which this backstory is presented, both through the game's secrets/acheivements/collectibles, and through puppet-style stageplays in various locations within the tower. 

Though I did enjoy this game, I have to point out some personal critiques:

First, the game is very short. Granted, that's not a huge deal: not all Metroidvanias have to be 40 hour behemoths like Hollow Knight. But this probably has the record for the shortest Metroidvania I've ever played (Hue, the second shortest, took me about 7 hours to beat). I beat the story in about 5 hours, and that was with a lot of dying during the bosses. Which brings me to the more important point...

Secondly, the bosses feel very cheap. There is no health mechanic in the game, so if you take any damage at all, you die, And for the most part, that's fine: Hue is also like that. It makes sense in a puzzle game, because they want you to actually figure out the way to get through the level safely, not sacrifice health to get through a tough part. However, for Teslagrad's bosses, it means you have to beat them without taking any damage. Compared to bosses you see in games like Hollow Knight, Guacamelee, or Sundered, they're not especially hard, but they took me a fair amount of tries, just because I might mess up on one part, and then have to start over again. Maybe if you'rereally good, it may not be an issue, but I did find it to be fairly annoying at times.

All in all, though, I had quite a bit of fun. If you can find it on sale, give it a try.

Fun little puzzle-platforming Metroidvania. Not a great deal of depth to the mechanics or story, which is good for the former and slightly bad for the latter. Soundtrack was nice too.

My main complaint is that some segments were sequences of easy bits strung together with a hard bit or two mixed in, and when you died, you had to redo the easy bits, making the game a little tedious. (This also applied to the boss fights.)

Boss fights (5 in total) were mostly a pain, but the last 2 were really fun, even though all fights required you to play flawlessly (because 1HKO - I died a [i]lot[/i] in this game). The first boss fight was on a treadmill moving from an electric barrier to a furnace, the second was on sloped ground (hard to "blink" across), and the third was a bullet-hell obstacle course (although much of it was still skippable). The last two fights are fun because you get to use all abilities effectively, and on even ground (although they are noticeably longer fights than the first three). The final boss even shares a few similarities to that of Castlevania's, by virtue of being a teleporting Big Bad in a red cape who shoots wave-projectiles at you.

There are two "endings", with the "good" one being slightly extended, but collecting all 36 scrolls (each with a corresponding achievement) just to see it would leave you disappointed, so I'd recommend only collecting them for the extra challenge.

Would recommend if you want to try out a puzzle-platformer (and this game does have a Demo on Steam), but not if you're looking for something to play because you're already completely bored.

3 hours to finish the game? I did not expect that, Teslagrad. 

[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]Graphics are cartoony and look great. I liked the way the main character looked in particular.
[*]The puzzles make for a good challenge. I really had to think outside the box a couple of times but I never got stuck for long. 
[*]Storytelling is done without talking, but occasionally you run into a "theater room" that tells you important things of the story.
[*]The equipment items that you collect are original and a fun improvement to your gameplay every time.  
[*]The OST is pretty good.
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]The game is super short! Just when you've gotten all the upgrades, all that is left is [spoiler]2 bosses which have just a few linear screens in between them[/spoiler] and you're done. This was really a massive dissapointment as you get a really cool upgrade at the end.
[*]I thought there would be lots of areas to explore because on the steam store screenshots & trailer the surroundings seemed very different every time, but it turned out that what you see is literally 1 room and then the next one has a different theme. Same goes for puzzles; most of them were really well thought and had unique things to keep in mind, but they literally used it once.  
[*]There is also a system in place where you have to find all of the 36 hidden scrolls throughout the game map for a special ending. Right before the end of the story, the game forces you to get at least 15 of them (if you put in a small effort, chances are that you already have enough by the time you get there). I feel like this a very cheap way to extend your playthrough's lifespan, and even then I finished the game in 3 hours. 
[*]This game has a metroidvania tag but it really barely is a metroidvania. It's a linear ride until you get near the end of the story where you have to at least 15 scrolls before you enter the final rooms, and at that point [spoiler]you can go back through the entire castle with all your upgrades at once to get all 36[/spoiler]. I would expect that a decent metroidvania has far more backtracking and deeper branching paths than this (paths do branch sometimes, but very shortly up to the point that you rarely even leave the room). There is no health system that you can find/get upgrades for, no extra ammunition/mana/energy resource upgrades as those systems are not in the game. It's just uselesss scrolls that you look for as a bonus, so finding one doesn't even feel rewarding.
[*]Some of the game's mechanics don't always work. I even got stuck at some point where the puzzle bugged out and I has to restart the game. 
[*]Speaking of restarts, I had to restart twice because the screen stayed black after death. I could still move and hear various elements around me. 
[*]Bosses are literally a game of memory. They have 1 pattern and when you see it the first time you are very likely to die ([i]no telegraphed moves here, is this your way of making things harder?[/i]), then the second time you adapt and get further into the battle. Rinse & repeat and the boss dies eventually. It would have been a much greater challenge if a boss at least randomizes it's moves a little. 
[/list]

Seeing how many positive reviews this game gets I didn't see it coming that this game would actually be such a dissapointment.

43629950.review:
If you're looking for an action-packed edge-of-your-seat split-second-reflexes platformer, you're looking in the wrong place.

If you're looking for a clever puzzle-platformer with a really cool, unique take on what it means to be a "hero"...

if you're looking for a game that tells a surprisingly sad story using dramatic, thoughtful narrative techniques which don't involve any reading or sitting through dialogue-based cutscenes...

or if you're looking for a quiet, fun, retro-inspired indie adventure with hand-drawn graphics and a beautiful soundtrack...

you should already have bought Teslagrad.

The game's backstory unfolds as you play, mostly through the use of clockwork "actors" miming history plays on stages placed throughout the game.  More story appears as you explore some of the abandoned areas of the castle.  At first, I admit, I didn't think there was anything particularly special about the story... but I was caught off-guard by a plot twist and a couple moments of character developments that really helped drive home the game's melancholy mood.

The sense of sadness that grows in subtle ways throughout the game ended up being my favorite part of it.  The puzzles are great, the player character's powers are really cool, and the boss enemies are well-designed, so there was already a lot to love.

Despite all these great features, the mood is really what left me loving the game.  I wasn't even aware of it for probably the first 2/3 of the game, but when it hit, it really got me.  The wistful music, the kingdom's troubled history, and the pure innocence of the main character all combine to make this probably the most memorable narrative I've ever seen in a platformer.

In case this doesn't sell you on Teslagrad, I'll break it down a bit more.

Controls: 8/10 (this is always a big deal in a platformer)
Graphics: 8.5/10
Boss fights (very few other enemies): 8/10
Puzzle mechanics: 9/10
Story/music/environment/etc: 10/10

Telsagrad is a very unique puzzle platformer and a classic indie title with a fresh idea, but not without its flaws.

The game fully utalizes its idea of polarity and I was pleasantly surprised for all of the totally unique challenges I was faced with over time. The hand drawn art, effects and music all mesh together excellently and the silent story told through lore was done very well. By the time I completed the game I knew the history of different kingdoms involved and how the main character played a part. I played this with a friend watching and he was very captivated by the mechanics the whole time. I will be honest, the game didn't do as much as I hoped with the polarity mechanic by the time it was finished but that's just because the developers at Rain did such an excellent job with showing me all of the possibilities the game already has and making me want even more Telsagrad ideas for a sequel or DLC.

Going into it you should be aware of two things.

1. This game is physics simulated leaving it to feel way more floaty than I wished, this means that many things can be down to bad luck with many unsatisfying deaths that couldnt have been prevented in that given dice roll. However if you are mindful and careful on how you use the polarity then things become much more predictable it's just much too sensitive for it to be very pick up and play. I didn't 100% the game but I got a good chunk of it completed about 90%, but thats not without a good chunk of it being trial and error. A few areas I can pinpoint to having being stuck in for a long period of time just due to how slippery physics are and I needed to find the exact right way to approach it, but the overall experience was well worth it to overcome these big hurdles.

2. This mixes casual puzzle platforming with hardcore old school reflexes, So your dexterity and quick thinking will be tested. The shift is most apparent when you're fighting a boss. The first time I encountered the bosses I felt like it was out of place due to the difficulty spike but became more accustomed to it over the course of the game ramping up with more challenge in the later levels. I  just wish it had a better balance to the learning curve instead of a big spike with each boss. If you don't like oldschool games that force you to memorize patterns then you won't like these parts of the game. You can easily spend a half hour on slowly learning how to finally beat a boss because you only get one life and no checkpoints here.

Mixed feelings about this one.  Teslagrad starts off on the right foot, then shoots itself in the foot.

The art direction is wonderful.  That's probably a big part of why you're thinking of buying this game.  And the puzzles are, for the most part, enjoyable and interesting.

I went into this expecting a puzzle-driven game like Blocks That Matter, Trine, Gunpoint, Tetrobot and Co., or maybe even Limbo. Unfortunately for me, I was wrong: to me, Teslagrad ends up feeling much more like Super Meat Boy or VVVVVV.

The puzzle design is fine - I actually liked the magnetic puzzle mechanics themselves, and wish they were used a bit more interestingly. There's plenty of potential, with robots and enemies and all kinds of mechanisms scattered throughout the game. But the puzzles don't really get more interesting or clever as the game goes on - instead, the game increases its challenge by requiring increasingly precise timing and control to actually execute on the solution to each puzzle. Checkpoints are not particularly generous, either, which makes the many sections with deathtraps especially irritating.

I hate this kind of game. I'd much rather spend ten minutes of my time figuring out how to solve a puzzle than spend five minutes trying to execute the precise timing of a solution I figured a few seconds after encountering the puzzle. I persisted because the pacing of overall progress feels so quick - it feels like the kind of game you should be able to get through in an afternoon or two of practice.

Unfortunately, after completing four of the five boss fights, the game asks you to rerun through the entire game to find 15 of the previously-optional, hard-to-reach collectibles. Without them, you can't reach the final area. I already had 7 and this was still irritating to do, and the game smugly suggests you really ought to collect all 36 collectibles in order to get the proper ending, though at least that's mercifully optional.

If you love platformers that require very good twitch skills and pattern-learning in order to succeed, you might enjoy this; for an indie game, it's decent if unremarkable in technical and artistic terms. But if you're looking for a puzzle-platformer where most of your effort goes into figuring out how the heck to solve a weird puzzle room, and you like that feeling of satisfaction after [i]finally understanding[/i] the design, stay away from this.

35757439.review:
Telsagrad starts you off slowly. As you go room to room solving problems and collecting upgrades, it seems like this will be a puzzle game with some minor platforming; a light metroidvania with only a couple of upgrades but plenty of backtracking to use them. Then, about two-thirds into the game, the difficulty spikes dramatically and something becomes very clear. Just like its namesake, Teslagrad is in love with the scientific method. The setting – despite all of its electricity and wild inventions – is just a red herring. No, this game's appreciation of science goes deeper than simple aesthetics. At a fundamental level, the only way to best this game's challenges is through meticulous experimentation. 

Death is instant from any source of damage and results in a respawn to the beginning of the room with no other penalty. In the early game this isn't really noticeable. If you were having any trouble making it through a room, it just meant you hadn't really learned the lesson it was trying to teach you yet. Once dangers start to appear more quickly than one can react, however, you're encouraged to die constantly and to use your mistakes to painstakingly memorize patterns rather than to use the cleverness or calm observation that suited the first two-thirds of the game. In this late game, you've gone from an eager student to a desperate researcher that will now earn his knowledge through blood, sweat, and tears.

Not a single word is ever written or spoken in Teslagrad. The plot instead must be interpreted through scenery, through silent puppet shows, and from the 36 scrolls scattered throughout the game. The scrolls themselves only provide a historical illustration of the tower you're struggling through and insight into motivations of the people who built it. Individually, none of these things make up a complete narrative; only when pieced together do they form something coherent. So just like the rest of the game, the story requires a careful analysis but promises great rewards to the persistent and the determined.

34090006.review:
[I]Teslagrad[/I] is a physics-based puzzle-platformer, tending towards a 'Metroidvania' in some respects. The game's puzzles are largely based around a magnetism mechanic and manipulation of attraction/repulsion of differently/similarly magnetised objects - including the player character himself - with a small range of tools. There are certainly some clever ideas here, but unfortunately my abiding feeling about [I]Teslagrad[/I] is of frustration, as I found many scenarios to be very fiddly, with behaviour not readily predictable - it was a case while it became clear what was needed, actually doing that was far from easy... but not for what felt like a lack of 'skill'.

Puzzle mechanics aside, while the game takes place almost all within a single building, there's a reasonably decent variety of environments. Graphics are simple but functional and the background music, while again simple, is catchy in a positive way. [I]Teslagrad[/I] is a short game - if you know what you're doing (and are able to pull it off!), it could be completed within a couple of hours or less, but I wouldn't see that specifically to be a negative here, especially as the games feels like it pretty much exhausts the types of puzzle scenario that the magnetism mechanic allows, without a significant shake-up.

Overall, while I wouldn't go as far as to call [I]Teslagrad[/I] a [i]bad[/i] game, I couldn't really rate it anywhere better than average given the feelings of frustration that it leads to.
